channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: Panic, Bribes, Ditched Cars and a Dash on Foot: Portraits of Flight From Russia
item.description: A mountain pass into Georgia has become a choke point for Russians fleeing the country, many of them men who faced being drafted and sent to fight in Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Ksenia Ivanova and Catherine Porter
item.media:credit: Ksenia Ivanova for The New York Times
item.media:description: Sergei with his two children Daniil, 10, and Karina, 10, in a hotel room in Stepatsminda, Georgia.

item.title: Putin Announces Ukraine Annexation, Calling West the Enemy
item.description: Declaring that Russia would annex four regions of Ukraine, which the West rejects as illegal, the Russian president accused the U.S. and its allies of “despotism’’ and “Satanism.’’
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski and Valerie Hopkins
item.media:credit: Alexander Nemenov/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia addressed a rally and concert in Red Square on Friday celebrating Russia’s illegal annexation of four Ukrainian provinces.

item.title: Safety Concerns Overshadow Europe’s First New Gas Link in Decades
item.description: Natural gas is set to flow through a new undersea pipeline between Norway and Poland after suspected sabotage devastated the Nord Stream pipelines.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Cezary Aszkielowicz/Agencja Wyborcza.Pl, via Reuters
item.media:description: The Goleniow Gas Compressor Station in Budno, Poland, is part of the new Baltic Pipe natural gas link between Norway and Poland.

item.title: Facing a Dire Storm Forecast in Florida, Officials Delayed Evacuation
item.description: A day of hesitation in Lee County came despite warnings that the Fort Myers and Cape Coral area could see mass flooding. Now authorities are encountering mass death.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles, Mike Baker, Serge F. Kovaleski and Lazaro Gamio
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tristan Stout, 22, surveying the damage to his father’s boat after it was moved across the street on San Carlos Island in Fort Myers Beach.

item.title: Another Challenge for Hardest-Hit Parts of Florida: Finding Clean Drinking Water
item.description: The worst trouble was in Lee County, where a badly damaged water system was affecting a population of nearly 760,000 people.
item.dc:creator: Campbell Robertson and Richard Fausset
item.media:credit: Jason Andrew for The New York Times
item.media:description: A Publix supermarket is open with limited hours in Cape Coral, Fla. The supermarket has no ice, propane or water.

item.title: In Florida’s Fort Myers Area, Scenes of Paradise May Be Lost for Good
item.description: On Fort Myers Beach, Sanibel Island and Pine Island, cherished landmarks and an easygoing existence were obliterated by Hurricane Ian.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Reed, Patricia Mazzei and Jack Healy
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Rescue workers in Fort Myers Beach on Thursday.

item.title: In China, Living Not ‘With Covid,’ but With ‘Zero Covid’
item.description: The country’s strict coronavirus restrictions dictate the patterns of daily life, like waiting in line for frequent Covid tests and stocking up on extra groceries in case of lockdown.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang
item.media:credit: Thomas Peter/Reuters
item.media:description: A Covid testing station in Beijing in September. The government ordered testing sites to be within a 15-minute walk in cities.

item.title: Half of Adults Have Heard Little or Nothing About New Covid Boosters, Survey Finds
item.description: The latest shots, which target Omicron and its subvariants, could offer protection against a winter surge in cases. But many people are unsure if they’re eligible.
item.dc:creator: Jan Hoffman
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Preparing a booster shot at a vaccination site in Maywood, Ill., this month.

item.title: Spending on Children Surged During the Pandemic. It Didn’t Last.
item.description: As programs expire, such federal spending is returning to prior levels: $1 for every $6 spent on older adults.
item.dc:creator: Claire Cain Miller
item.media:credit: Timothy Mulcare for The New York Times
item.media:description: “In my career, I’ve never seen anything so dramatic as the shift in resources to families with kids during the pandemic,” a Michigan professor said.

item.title: The Great Guinea Pig Giveaway Has Begun
item.description: From geckos to chinchillas, small pets were a pandemic balm. Now shelters across the country say they are being surrendered.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Maslin Nir
item.category: American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals
item.media:credit: Natalie Keyssar for The New York Times
item.media:description: Liliana Bravo, an adoption supervisor at a New York City animal shelter, holds one of the many guinea pigs to be surrendered in recent weeks. The City Council is considering a bill that would ban their sale in pet shops.

item.title: In Michigan, Tudor Dixon Tests Whether Trump Is Help or Hindrance
item.description: Tudor Dixon, the party’s nominee for governor, has ground to make up in her race against Gov. Gretchen Whitmer. She is hoping the former president can rally their party’s base.
item.dc:creator: Jazmine Ulloa
item.media:credit: Emily Elconin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Tudor Dixon won the Republican primary for governor of Michigan days after being endorsed by former President Donald J. Trump.

item.title: Trump Argues for Executive Privilege in Jan. 6 and Mar-a-Lago Inquiries
item.description: In both cases, former President Donald J. Trump is claiming a novel power to keep White House information from his time in office secret from the Justice Department.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Savage and Glenn Thrush
item.media:credit: Oliver Contreras for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump has claimed a broad interpretation of executive privilege in his legal battles since leaving the White House.

item.title: Brazil Faces Big Vote in Presidential Election: Bolsonaro vs. Lula.
item.description: Brazilians voting for president on Sunday will choose between two political titans in a contest seen as a major test for one of the world’s largest democracies.
item.dc:creator: Jack Nicas
item.media:credit: From left: Lalo de Almeida for The New York Times; Victor Moriyama for The New York Times
item.media:description: The challenger, former President Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, left, and the incumbent, President Jair Bolsonaro. Mr. da Silva leads in the polls.

item.title: British Ruling Pins Blame on Social Media for Teenager’s Suicide
item.description: The internet, according to the ruling, “affected her mental health in a negative way and contributed to her death in a more than minimal way.”
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano
item.media:credit: Jonathan Clifford for The New York Times
item.media:description: A photo album of Molly Russell, who died in November 2017.

item.title: How Hard Should Your Workout Be?
item.description: Every strenuous exercise involves some mixture of suffering and pleasure. The key to sticking with it is getting the balance right.
item.dc:creator: Alex Hutchinson
item.media:credit: Sean Dong

item.title: Putin Is Turning Russia Into a Giant North Korea
item.description: He has set in motion forces that are turning Russia into a giant North Korea.
item.dc:creator: Thomas L. Friedman
item.media:credit: Agence France-Presse — Getty Images

item.title: Vladimir Putin’s ‘Medea’
item.description: What does Vlad the Impaler have in store for the world?
item.dc:creator: Maureen Dowd
item.media:credit: Sputnik, via Reuters
item.media:description: President Vladimir Putin held a ceremony Friday to declare the annexation of four regions in Ukraine.

item.title: Putin’s Speech Just Told Us His Ukraine War Plans
item.description: Amid the bluster and veiled threats, the president made three distinct points that form a blueprint for war and peace.
item.dc:creator: Alexander Baunov
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Grigory Sysoyev

item.title: Big Tech Should Support the Iranian People, Not the Regime
item.description: Western technology companies, recently freed from sanctions, should grant full access to Iranians.
item.dc:creator: Mahsa Alimardani, Kendra Albert and Afsaneh Rigot
item.media:credit: Markus Schreiber/Associated Press

item.title: The Supreme Court Is Broken. Where’s Biden?
item.description: Why is the president sitting this out?
item.dc:creator: Jeff Shesol
item.media:credit: Pablo Delcan

item.title: How the Remote Work Craze Made Housing Affordability Worse
item.description: How the affordability crisis got even worse.
item.dc:creator: Paul Krugman
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; images by Tom Werner and GCShutter, via Getty Images

item.title: If Bolsonaro Loses Brazil’s Election, Will He Respect the Result?
item.description: Brazilians are holding our breath.
item.dc:creator: Vanessa Barbara
item.media:credit: Silvia Izquierdo/Associated Press
item.media:description: A man in a shirt with the image of Luiz Inácio Lula da Silva, who is seeking to regain Brazil’s presidency, in Rio de Janeiro on Sunday

item.title: Making Friends
item.description: A psychologist and friendship expert has advice for how to make friends as an adult.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Kirsch

item.title: Did Your Home Security Camera Document Hurricane Ian?
item.description: We want to hear from you.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Hilary Swift for The New York Times
item.media:description: Destruction from Hurricane Ian on Thursday in Fort Myers Beach, Fla.

item.title: The Run-Up: American Evangelicalism and the Midterm Elections
item.description: A new class of American evangelical leaders is shaking up the Republican Party — and raising the stakes of the midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: ‘The Run-Up’ Team
item.media:credit: Evelyn Hockstein/For The Washington Post via Getty Images

item.title: A Strong Dollar Is Hurting Other Countries. Should the Fed Care?
item.description: Experts disagree.
item.dc:creator: Peter Coy
item.media:credit: Illustration by The New York Times; images by CSA Images, via Getty Images

item.title: Eric Adams Confidant Is Among New York’s Highest Paid Public Employees
item.description: The city had initially declined to reveal the salary of Timothy Pearson, who left a second job at a casino over the summer.
item.dc:creator: Michael Rothfeld, Dana Rubinstein and William K. Rashbaum
item.media:credit: Gabriela Bhaskar/The New York Times
item.media:description: Mayor Eric Adams, right, hired Timothy Pearson, center, in May.

item.title: New Burkina Faso Coup Raises Question About Security
item.description: A military officer removed another military leader who had seized power only eight months ago. Whether he can do better is another question.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat
item.media:credit: Olympia De Maismont/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A military vehicle outside Burkina Faso’s national television offices on Saturday in Ouagadougou, the capital. The coup within a coup was announced on national TV.

item.title: Fentanyl Test Strips Highlight Rift in Nation’s Struggle to Combat Drug Deaths
item.description: Proponents say the ability to check drugs for the presence of lethal fentanyl may save lives. But critics say the strips enable drug use.
item.dc:creator: Jan Hoffman and Desiree Rios
item.media:credit: Desiree Rios/The New York Times

item.title: Battered by Floods and Trapped in Debt, Pakistani Farmers Struggle to Survive
item.description: The recent flooding has plunged small farmers in sharecropping arrangements further into debt with their landlords — a cycle that has worsened as extreme weather events become increasingly common.
item.dc:creator: Christina Goldbaum, Zia ur-Rehman and Kiana Hayeri
item.media:credit: Kiana Hayeri for The New York Times

item.title: The Worst Foods and Drinks for Your Teeth
item.description: When assessing how likely a given meal, snack or drink is to harm your dental health, there are two main things to consider, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Hannah Seo
item.media:credit: Kelsey McClellan for The New York Times

item.title: Is Seltzer Water Just as Healthy as Flat Water?
item.description: Unsweetened carbonated water is a better choice than soda or fruit juice. But don’t overdo it, experts say.
item.dc:creator: Christina Caron
item.media:credit: Aileen Son for The New York Times

item.title: If Food Is Love, My Kids Must Hate Me
item.description: Growing up, I equated great meals with a healthy family dynamic. My children couldn’t care less.
item.dc:creator: Chaunie Brusie

item.title: Can You Get Over a Food Intolerance?
item.description: Foods most often associated with intolerances were chocolate, food additives, citrus fruits, fish, shellfish, milk, cheese, eggs and nuts.
item.dc:creator: Richard Klasco, M.D.
item.media:credit: Getty Images

item.title: A Sneaker With a Built-In Puddle
item.description: Thinking about oceans of plastic at Paris Fashion Week.
item.dc:creator: Jessica Testa

item.title: How to Solve Intermediate Crosswords
item.description: Moving up to the Wednesday and Thursday puzzles.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Frere and Isaac Aronow
item.media:credit: Thomas Merceron
